name: Water Use Restrictions - Summary of 15 RCNY Chapters 20 and 21
description: A summary of the restrictions placed on water use during non-emergency and drought emergency conditions.

columns.name: Non Emergency Restrictions (including Normal, Drought Watch and Drought Warning conditions)

cachedContents.smallest: Hoses and sprinklers prohibited November 1 -  March 31, and also during other months from 11am to 7 pm. Automatic sprinklers must have a rain sensor.

top.item: Non-commercial: Hose must have a self-closing nozzle.  Commercial: At least 75% of water must be recirculated or well water
Prohibited November 1 -  March 31, and also during other months from 11 am to 7 pm.
Hoses and sprinklers prohibited November 1 -  March 31, and also during other months from 11 am to 7 pm. Automatic sprinklers must have a rain sensor.
Hoses and sprinklers prohibited November 1 -  March 31, and also during other months from 11am to 7 pm. Automatic sprinklers must have a rain sensor.
Sale or installation of products using more than 2.5 gpm is prohibited
Over 6 tons of refrigeration or 2 tons of AC is prohibited
Properties with steam-source refrigeration must use some condensate for cooling tower make-up.

cachedContents.smallest: All showerheads in use must use 2.5 gpm or less

top.item: Prohibited except where required by law or health and safety rules, or if well water is used
Prohibited, except as required by Code or health and safety rules
Further restricted to 7-9 am and 7-9 pm, even number addresses on even dates, odd number addresses on odd dates. Golf courses may water only tees and greens.
Only hand-held watering containers, hoses restricted to less than 5 gpm, or low-pressure/low-flow irrigation can be used
DEP Commissioner may ask the New York City Water Board to consider a "Drought Emergency Contingency Rate Plan" to increase rates to encourage conservation during the Emergency.
Must recirculate, fill 1 time per year, top off minimally as needed
All showerheads in use must use 2.5 gpm or less
Over 2 tons of either is prohibited

cachedContents.smallest: DEP Commissioner may ask the New York City Water Board to consider a "Drought Emergency Contingency Rate Plan" to increase rates to encourage conservation during the Emergency.
cachedContents.largest: Same as Stage I except use of hand-held containers is limited to recycled water or (if not feasible) to the minimum amount necessary to prevent permanent plant damage.

top.item: Same as Stage I except use of hand-held containers is limited to recycled water or (if not feasible) to the minimum amount necessary to prevent permanent plant damage.
DEP Commissioner may ask the New York City Water Board to consider a "Drought Emergency Contingency Rate Plan" to increase rates to encourage conservation during the Emergency.
Only pools open to the public may be filled or maintained

cachedContents.smallest: DEP Commissioner may ask the New York City Water Board to consider a "Drought Emergency Contingency Rate Plan" to increase rates to encourage conservation during the Emergency.
cachedContents.largest: Same as Stage II except wherever possible use recycled or well water (before using City water) for watering all plant material.

top.item: Same as Stage II except wherever possible use recycled or well water (before using City water) for watering all plant material.
DEP Commissioner may ask the New York City Water Board to consider a "Drought Emergency Contingency Rate Plan" to increase rates to encourage conservation during the Emergency.
Indoor air dry-bulb temperature must be 79 degrees minimum. Health care facilities are exempt. EDP facilities are exempt but must provide proof of maximum temp. tolerated by equipment.
